title: If the white King in chess cannot make a legal move but is not in check and has no other pieces is it a stalemate or win for black? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends. Stalemate conditions: 1: It must be your turn to move. 2: You are not in check. 3. You have no legal moves that you can make (and you must not put yourself in check). Instances where the question asked would not be stalemate: 1: You don’t have a legal move but it’s also not your turn to move. Once your opponent moves it’s possible that the position will change and then you’re no longer in stalemate. 2: You aren’t defining pawns as pieces for some reason. If you can move a lawn, there’s no stalemate. 3. You don’t have any legal moves and just have a king. But it’s their turn to move. They run out of time ⌛️. They lose.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Kristian Xavier LaVey

response.answer_text: That would be stalemate, which is counted as a draw. Sometimes, stalemate can feel almost like a win for white, e.g. if black actually had ways to win yet stumbled into a stalemate trap. Or it might feel more like a win for black if white was winning (white would need to have other pieces in this case). Both cases are possible, but either way, it’s a draw.
